verses.text: My son, keep my words and treasure my commandments within you.
verses.comment: Solomon urges his son to internalize his teachings, indicating the value of sacred tradition and faithful observance.

verses.text: Keep my commandments and live; guard my teaching as the apple of your eye.
verses.comment: Obedience is connected with life. The 'apple of your eye' echoes God’s special care for His people (cf. Deut. 32:10).

verses.text: Bind them on your fingers; write them on the tablet of your heart.
verses.comment: The imagery recalls the physical reminders of the law in Deuteronomy 6:8, emphasizing continual remembrance and inward transformation.

verses.text: Say to wisdom, 'You are my sister,' and call understanding your close relative,
verses.comment: Wisdom and understanding are to be cherished as intimately as family, suggesting the role of spiritual kinship in guiding the faithful.

verses.text: to keep you from the immoral woman, from the stranger with her smooth words.
verses.comment: The 'immoral woman' represents not just literal temptation but also spiritual infidelity—worldly wisdom that leads away from God’s covenant.

verses.text: For at the window of my house, I looked out through my lattice,
verses.comment: The scene shifts to a fatherly warning through a personal observation—Solomon as a wise observer, underscoring the need for vigilance.

verses.text: and I saw among the naive, I discerned among the youths, a young man lacking sense,
verses.comment: The 'youth lacking sense' serves as a warning to those without spiritual maturity or discernment, stressing the need for guidance in all ages.

verses.text: passing along the street near her corner, taking the road to her house
verses.comment: Movement toward danger is intentional. This demonstrates free will and responsibility—paralleling man’s choice between good and evil (Gen. 2:16-17).

verses.text: in the twilight, in the evening, in the black and dark of night.
verses.comment: Darkness often symbolizes sin and secrecy—see parallels in John 3:19-20, where evil deeds are concealed in darkness.

verses.text: And look, a woman came out to meet him, dressed like a prostitute and with crafty intent.
verses.comment: The seductive approach represents both physical and spiritual dangers—temptations that lure believers away from truth and discipline.

verses.text: She is loud and rebellious; her feet do not stay at home.
verses.comment: 'Loud and rebellious' contrasts with the peace found in communion with God, reflecting the disorder that comes from abandoning divine wisdom.

verses.text: Now she is in the streets, now in the squares; she lurks at every corner.
verses.comment: Temptation is pervasive—modern contexts also echo this, calling for vigilance and involvement in a disciplined community for protection.

verses.text: So she caught him and kissed him, and with a bold face she said to him:
verses.comment: The aggressiveness of temptation contrasts with the prudent, patient love modeled by God. The embrace is a counterfeit of covenant love.

verses.text: 'I had to offer peace offerings; today I have paid my vows.'
verses.comment: She seeks to cloak sin with religious deeds—a warning against hypocrisy and the misuse of ritual apart from heartfelt obedience.

verses.text: So I came out to meet you, to diligently seek your face, and I have found you.
verses.comment: The false sense of being 'chosen' by temptation parodies the earnest pursuit found in authentic spiritual seeking (cf. Song of Solomon).

verses.text: I have spread my couch with coverings, colored linens from Egypt.
verses.comment: Luxury and sensuality are seen here as tools of seduction, urging a contrast with life devoted to worship and self-sacrifice.

verses.text: I have perfumed my bed with myrrh, aloes, and cinnamon.
verses.comment: Imagery parallels the perfumes used in temple worship, highlighting the distortion of what is sacred when used for sinful purposes.

verses.text: 'Come, let us drink our fill of love until morning; let us delight ourselves with love.'
verses.comment: The misuse of 'love' here is selfish and fleeting, opposed to the faithful, covenantal love between God and His people.

verses.text: For my husband is not at home; he has gone on a long journey.
verses.comment: Secrecy hides sin, yet nothing is hidden from God (Heb. 4:13). The reference to the absent husband further parallels spiritual unfaithfulness.

verses.text: He took a bag of money with him; he will not come home until the full moon.
verses.comment: The expectation of impunity emboldens wrongdoing, but divine justice is sure. There is a temporal patience but eventual reckoning.

verses.text: With her many persuasive words she led him astray; with her smooth talk she seduced him.
verses.comment: The power of words to deceive recalls the serpent’s temptation in Genesis 3:1-6, highlighting the need for discernment and truth.

verses.text: All at once he follows her, like an ox goes to the slaughter, like a deer caught in a trap,
verses.comment: Sin leads to destruction. The animal imagery stresses the inevitability and unawareness of the consequences when one departs from wisdom.

verses.text: until an arrow pierces its liver; like a bird rushing into a snare, not knowing it will cost him his life.
verses.comment: The fatal consequence of moral failure highlights the seriousness of spiritual purity. The warning applies beyond the literal narrative.

verses.text: Now, sons, listen to me, and pay attention to the words of my mouth.
verses.comment: The father’s repeated admonition echoes the biblical pattern of generational transmission of faith and wisdom (cf. Deut. 6:7).

verses.text: Do not let your heart turn aside to her ways; do not stray into her paths.
verses.comment: Guarding the heart is central in scripture (Prov. 4:23), signifying the importance of inner transformation, not just external compliance.

verses.text: For she has brought down many wounded; indeed, all her slain are a mighty army.
verses.comment: Many have fallen to temptation, emphasizing the universality of the struggle with sin and the need for steadfastness in true worship and discipline.

verses.text: Her house is the way to Sheol, going down to the chambers of death.
verses.comment: The 'way to Sheol' is a symbol of spiritual death. The ultimate consequence of unrepented sin is separation from God—a sobering call to repentance and right relationship through faith and sacrament.
